prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Appropriate physical restrictions on access to confidential information need to be in place. Such restrictions will include the physical location of the information and any devices such as locks, barriers and security codes which limit access. It is often useful to have employee photo identification cards. These cards can be numbered and used to electronically control access. The cards are particularly useful for controlling after-hours access to premises, and they provide the means to track entry and exit.

Access to sensitive documents should be limited, and each individual responsible for such information should have an appropriate cabinet or other facility in which such documents may be locked. Other measures such as security alarms, fences and guards will provide further safety for business information. Normally, where an area has been secured so as to prevent easy access, where the area is marked by signs such as “No Admission” or “Authorized Entry Only”, or where verbal warnings have been given, the courts will be inclined to protect the information in question.[1] As to verbal warnings, however, while they may be sufficient, it is sometimes difficult to prove that such warnings were provided. A simple way around this issue is to ensure that those with potential access to sensitive information receive written notice concerning the sensitivity of the information. Further, a signed acknowledgment regarding the receipt and review of any relevant company policies may be obtained. In addition, more general policy statements regarding confidentiality should be contained in office manuals, employee handbooks and workplace memos. These sources should clearly outline the company's policy and the specific measures that must be taken to ensure compliance.
International Tools Ltd. v. Kollar (1968), 67 D.L.R. (2d) 386, [1968] 1 O.R. 669 (C.A.).
